Message.Title: IBM Buyback
Message.Msg: Question .Dos the stock that IBM buys as part of its billion dollar buyback program show up as part of the stock activity for the day?.

When IBM buys back shares it is reported unless it is a privately negotiated trade. When IBM issues shares against option exercise I suspect they buy them as part of the overall buyback. The amount that IBM publishes is its buyback amount for the prior quarter is gross purchases of both public stock and private deals, if any. If you account for options, about 20% to 23% of the gross cash IBM spends comes back to IBM from the proceeds of option exercise. You can see it by comparing the amounts on IBM's cash flow statements to the quarterly gross amount IBM lists in the earnings PR. So it's the cost of IBM stock comp -- the employee pays the exercise and IBM pays him the difference between his price and market value. IBM has a policy of issuing new stock options at 110% of market -- so IBM options come with a standard time vesting as well as price performance vesting to be worth anything. There are no doubt exceptions by the BOD but the general rule is 110%.. I guess they felt that was fair because of IBM's commitment to share buybacks. It's a good practice. IBM's relentless share buybacks made it a good bet for start ups who will benefit from being acquired to sell into IBM's base. While IBM usually pays net cash for acquisitions, IBM makes individual employment deals with start ups or mature operations staff to join IBM. The buybacks assure that they won't be diluted by future acquisitions.

Message.Title: Can someone ...
Message.Msg: tell me whats going on in the after hours action? --I know there is jitters w. the earnings soon after Oracle and far east issues
Absolutely ridicules.. What news???. That 1 of the most insane things I have seen..... WQhat a BuncH on B . S

This afterhours action is not new. Its been going ion for some time. I wonder if it has to due the buyback program of IBM. I don't know the volume of stock being traded afterhours. Any incite would help

I'm wondering too. Unfortunately it seems as though most message boards are filled with illiterate morons who can"t write a cohesive sentence and have no worthwhile information. I've owned this stock over 25 years and have held back from selling the last two times it hit 215, I think I will get out next time and get back in lower.

It's ACN -- Accenture. It just posted results and revenue was weaker than expected and they took their full year est down. Their consulting fees were down -- their EPS range had a low of $4.24 and the new range has a high of $4.22 -- so it's hard to say but it looks like about a $.10 EPS reduction on about a base of $4.30 so about a 2.5% reduction. It's going to hurt IBM. ACN has been a much better performer than IBM in the last 18 months. And I believe it has around a 16 p/e so better growth has been expected for ACN over IBM. We'll see -- IBM has looked weak in the last few days -- looks like a haircut tomorrow.
